class_description: Deprecated high-level aggregate for flowering plant reproduction. This class was previously used to bundle organisms (flowering plants), reproductive processes (pollination), and structures, but has been superseded by more specific classes: Plant Reproductive Structures, Pollination (Flowering Plant Process), and Flowering Plants (Organisms). It is retained only for backward compatibility and should not receive new members.
evidence_excerpt: Pollination transfers pollen between flowers, enabling plant reproduction; plants are the organisms whose reproduction is assisted.
remarks: This class has been structurally split into separate process (pollination) and organism (flowering plants) classes and may now have no direct members; consider deprecating or repurposing in a later cleanup pass.

This class has no members and its original scope is now cleanly covered by ClsC_fb0a1cd7 (Plant Reproductive Structures), ClsR_9ddc1c4b (Pollination (Flowering Plant Process)), and ClsR_2f847eb5 (Flowering Plants (Organisms)). Treat this as a deprecated aggregate container; avoid assigning new entities here and migrate any legacy members into the more specific classes.

members.entity_description: Shared mental creativity of a group that generates stories and myths.
members.resolution_context: While some stories may be based on real events or historical figures, many urban legends are the product of collective imagination and creativity.

members.entity_description: Cultural preferences that shape how stories are adapted and retold.
members.resolution_context: These tales were often shared orally, passed down from one generation to the next, and evolved over time to suit the interests and fears of different cultures.

members.entity_description: Shared mental and cultural space where societies generate, store, and transform urban legends.
members.resolution_context: As long as there are mysteries to be solved and fears to be faced, urban legends will continue to thrive in the collective imagination of society.

members.entity_description: The capacity of urban legends to amuse, thrill, or engage audiences as a form of entertainment.
members.resolution_context: The allure of the unknown and the thrill of a good scare have contributed to the enduring popularity of these types of urban legends. In addition to their entertainment value, urban legends serve as cautionary tales that reflect the fears and anxieties of society.

members.entity_description: Human capacity to invent and elaborate imaginative stories like urban legends.
members.resolution_context: While some stories may be based on real events or historical figures, many urban legends are the product of collective imagination and creativity.

class_description: Biological and anatomical structures and materials involved in butterfly metamorphosis, including larval body structures, dissolved organs and liquefied material, the chrysalis, and newly forming tissues and appendages such as wings and antennae.
evidence_excerpt: Organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form.

members.entity_description: Internal biological structures of the caterpillar that dissolve during metamorphosis.
members.resolution_context: Its organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form. This describes internal caterpillar organs breaking down during metamorphosis inside the chrysalis.

members.entity_description: Liquid-like biological material formed when caterpillar organs dissolve inside the chrysalis during metamorphosis.
members.resolution_context: Its organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form. The phrase indicates a liquefied intermediate state during metamorphosis.

members.entity_description: Fresh biological tissues that develop from liquefied organs during metamorphosis.
members.resolution_context: Its organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form. This indicates formation of new biological tissues as part of transformation into a butterfly.

members.entity_description: Sensory appendages that develop as new structures during butterfly metamorphosis.
members.resolution_context: Its organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form. Antennae are listed among structures that develop from the liquefied state inside the chrysalis.

members.entity_description: The hardened, protective casing enclosing the pupa stage of a butterfly, within which metamorphosis occurs and from which the adult butterfly emerges.

members.entity_description: The overall physical structure of the caterpillar, including its tissues and organs, that changes significantly during metamorphosis.
members.resolution_context: During metamorphosis, the caterpillar's body undergoes significant changes as it develops into a butterfly.

class_description: Organisms that act as predators within ecosystems, influencing prey species such as caterpillars and shaping ecological dynamics.

members.resolution_context: Some caterpillars have spines or hairs for protection, while others mimic the appearance of twigs or leaves to camouflage themselves from predators. Predators here are the threat that these adaptations aim to avoid.

class_description: The rapid increase in size and mass experienced by caterpillars during the larval stage.

members.resolution_context: Caterpillars are voracious eaters and spend most of their time feeding on leaves and growing rapidly.

class_description: The periodic shedding and replacement of a caterpillar's external skin (integument) during growth.
evidence_excerpt: Caterpillars grow rapidly and shed their skin several times as they grow.

members.entity_description: Biological process in which caterpillars shed and replace their external skin multiple times as they grow.
members.resolution_context: They shed their skin several times as they grow, a process known as molting. Each time they molt, they reveal a new, larger skin underneath. This describes the repeated shedding of skin as caterpillars increase in size.
